awd_titl_txt: Meeting: Advancing the Accessibility of Digital Media for Biological Research in the 21st Century
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cornell Lab of Ornithology will convene a meeting of experts and stakeholders to address the challenges of archiving audiovisual data for the biological sciences. Audiovisual data useful to modern biological research (a.k.a. "media specimens") are recordings (audio, video, still images) of organisms in their natural habitats, collected by researchers and citizen scientists to create records of observations of biodiversity and animal behavior. Standards and best practices have not been widely adopted for such audiovisual data, particularly in the biological sciences, and most existing data archives and biological research collections lack the expertise and infrastructure to manage it.  At the same time, biologists and other researchers are collecting vast amounts of such data, and this trend is increasing as recording technologies become more sophisticated and inexpensive, such that large scale research projects are based in part or in whole on media data (e.g., bioacoustic monitoring projects). Audiovisual data (audio and video recordings) require substantial "hands on" time for processing, large storage capacity for large files, rich descriptive metadata, and constant migration to new formats as technologies change. 

Participants in the meeting will develop a white paper that addresses explicitly the challenges of making audiovisual data broadly accessible and provide a framework that identifies and prioritizes key steps to reduce the likelihood of the loss of important data. Finally, several graduate students and postdocs will participate in the meeting itself, thereby providing a valuable experience and enhancing their training and background in data archiving and accessibility.

por.por_cntn:
The digital revolution has created new opportunities for data storage and access, leading to an atmosphere and expectation for open data sharing that will benefit the broader scientific community. These opportunities bring with them new challenges as well, and these can vary across data types and formats. For example, audiovisual data (audio and video recordings) contain a wealth of valuable information, yet carry with them significant challenges: substantial “hands on” time for processing, requirements for large storage capacity, standardized descriptive metadata, and constant migration to new formats as technologies change. Moreover, much of the audiovisual data collected in the recent past (and even today) is in analog format that requires digitization. Standards and best practices have not been widely discussed or adopted for such audiovisual data, particularly in the biological sciences, and most existing data archives and biological research collections lack the necessary expertise and infrastructure. As a consequence, audiovisual data remain prohibitively under-curated and broadly inaccessible to the biological research community. Yet, at the same time, biologists and other researchers are collecting vast amounts of such data, increasingly so as technologies evolve and recording technologies become more sophisticated and inexpensive, leading to large scale research projects based in part or in whole on media data (e.g., bioacoustic monitoring projects). These data will remain generally inaccessible, and likely will be lost, if the challenges of archiving digital media are not addressed.

This award, together with funds leveraged from other sources (in particular, the national digitization hub iDigBio and another NSF award), supported a meeting that brought together representatives and experts from several key stakeholder communities to discuss these issues and consider explicitly the challenges of archiving audiovisual data for the biological sciences. The meeting lasted three days and involved a total of 66 participants, including researchers and other professionals with expertise in museum collections, data archiving, biodiversity media, and imaging technologies. Topics covered included best practices for collection and archiving of biodiversity media, metadata standards, imaging of museum specimens, and advances in database technologies.

The main deliverable of the meeting will be a white paper, currently being written, that addresses explicitly the challenges of making audiovisual data broadly accessible. This report will develop a framework that identifies and prioritizes the key issues and make recommendations for the most important next steps, and so will be a key step toward finding sustainable solutions. Although some of the issues addressed will be unique to audiovisual data, others will be more broadly relevant to other data types, such that solutions for audiovisual data can help inform approaches to archiving other data types and vice versa. In addition, the issues and topics covered in this meeting are being incorporated into relevant chapters of a forthcoming book, entitle Ornithological Collections in the 21st Century: The Extended Specimen (Editor: Michael Webster), which is in the final stages of production and will be published in 2016. The white paper and publications resulting from this meeting will serve as a guide for future development of audiovisual data archival capacity, and as such will have clear and long lasting impacts on the broader research community.
